Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Metallic Coatings to Improve Protein Adhesion

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAPSI: Metallic Coatings to Improve Protein Adhesion

Award Number: 1015572

Aracely Rocha-Zapata

 

The goal of this research was to identify the potential use of nitrogen-based coatings for artificial body joints. One of the main issues that shorten the life of artificial joints is their normal wear during use. When two contacting surfaces are in motion, material will be removed, even at the microscopic scale. The material that is removed then is small enough to go through the muscle and other tissue around the artificial joint. These small particles can kill the tissue that they come in contact with.

One way to prevent this problem is by decreasing the amount of particles that are removed during normal use of an artificial joint. Adding nitrogen to metallic materials helps make a harder surface. In general, a harder surface means decreasing the amount of material removed. If the amount of material removal is decreased, then these implants will last longer decreasing pain, hospital and doctor costs for people using them. Nitrogen has been successfully added to chromium and titanium, two of the most common materials used for artificial joints. Furthermore, these treated materials have shown a significant decrease in material removal (up to 90% reduction).

Although these coating materials decrease material removal, it is also necessary to understand how the body will respond to them. Will the body accept these materials? Or will they cause an allergic reaction? One way of knowing this is by studying how well proteins or cells hold on to the surface. The stronger they attach to the surface, the better. Therefore, in this study, we measured how strongly proteins attach to the surface of these coating materials.

It was determined that the coating material does not affect the strength of protein attachment, that the coatings simply result in a harder surface that decreases material removal and do not affect how well the materials currently used bond with the body. In other words, it solves the problem of material removal while keeping the same connection with the tissues in the body.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2011
Modified by: Aracely Rocha-Zapata
